text:
*[Bug 18750] New: duplicated.data.frame() returns empty vector for zero-column data frames*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18750>

            Bug ID: 18750
           Summary: duplicated.data.frame() returns empty vector for
                    zero-column data frames
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.4.x
          Hardware: x86_64/x64/amd64 (64-bit)
                OS: Windows 64-bit
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Language
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:markwebster204@yahoo.co.uk|markwebster204@yahoo.co.uk>

duplicated.data.frame() should return, per the documentation, "a logical vector
with one element for each row."

For one or more columns, this is the case:

```
> x <- data.frame(a = rep(1, 5))
> duplicated(x)
[1] FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE
```

For zero columns, however, the result is an empty logical vector:

```
> duplicated(x[, FALSE])
logical(0)
```

This affects some other functions that use duplicated:

```
> unique(x[, FALSE]) # should return 1 row
data frame with 0 columns and 0 rows
```

text:
*[Bug 18751] New: Behaviour of packageDescription() depends on case of `pkg`*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18751>

            Bug ID: 18751
           Summary: Behaviour of packageDescription() depends on case of
                    `pkg`
           Product: R
           Version: R 4.4.x
          Hardware: All
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Misc
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:martin.smith@durham.ac.uk|martin.smith@durham.ac.uk>

`packageDescription()` and related functions (e.g. `packageVersion()`) behave
differently depending on whether or not the case of `pkg` is correct.


To reproduce:

1. Install a version of a package.  I installed version 1.11.1 of TreeTools.
2. Use `devtools::load_all()` to load a different version of the same package:
here, TreeTools 1.11.1.9003
3. Type `packageVersion("TreeTools")`.  Using the correct case returns the
version of the *loaded* package, 1.11.1.9003.
4. Type `packageVersion("TreeTOOLS")`.  Using the incorrect case returns the
version number of the *installed* package, 1.11.1.

Looking at the source, I suspect that this reflects the behaviour of the
function `isNamespaceLoaded(pkg)`, which only returns `TRUE` when `pkg`
exhibits the correct case.

I think the expected behaviour would be for the function to fail if the case of
the package is incorrectly specified, to be consistent with e.g.
`install.packages()`.

*[Bug 18751] Behaviour of packageDescription() depends on case of `pkg`*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18751>

Kurt Hornik (<mailto:Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at|Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at

--- Comment #1 from Kurt Hornik (<mailto:Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at|Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at>) ---
Not for me:

R> packageVersion("TreeTools")
[1] ‘1.11.1.9003’
R> packageVersion("TreeTOOLS")
Error in packageVersion("TreeTOOLS") : 
  there is no package called ‘TreeTOOLS’

Is this on a case-insensitive file system?
What happens if you do packageVersion("TreeTOOLS") without having
the namespace loaded?

elements.text: [Bug 18751] Behaviour of packageDescription() depends on case of

text:
*[Bug 18751] Behaviour of packageDescription() depends on case of `pkg`*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18751>

--- Comment #8 from Martin R. Smith (<mailto:martin.smith@durham.ac.uk|martin.smith@durham.ac.uk>) ---
Great, thanks.  I wondered whether there might be a solution using `dir`: e.g.

```
fun <- function(pkg, lib.loc = NULL) {
  pkgpath <- ""
  for (lib in lib.loc %||% .libPaths())
    if (file.access(file.path(lib, pkg), 5) == 0L) {
      libPkgs <- dir(lib)
      pkgpath <- file.path(lib, libPkgs[match(tolower(pkg), tolower(libPkgs))])
      break
    }
  pkgpath
}
```

In this case
`fun("TreeTools")` and `fun("TreeTOOLS")` return

`"C:/Users/[...]/My_Documents/R/win-library/4.1/TreeTools"`


I can see possible drawbacks -- for instance if two packages were installed
whose names differed only in case -- though I suspect this would be problematic
anyway on a case-insensitive file system?
